Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Understanding Stellar Forges: The Properties and the Physics of Formation of Cosmic Dust
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dust is a minor component of the interstellar medium but plays a major role in the evolution of the universe and on our capability to observe it. Dr. Lazzati and his group will combine analytical and numerical techniques to study dust particles of all sizes, from the smallest macromolecules and clusters up to micron-sized crystalline and amorphous solids. In the first part of the project structural and optical properties of small dust grains will be computed with density functional theory techniques. Atomic and molecular clusters with up to 1000 atoms will be studied. In the second part models of dust nucleation will be improved by developing a kinetic theory that includes realistic atomic structures, relaxes the assumption of thermal equilibrium, and includes quantization of energy exchanges. Finally, dust yields from stellar atmospheres and winds, supernovae, and AGN outflows will be computed. This project will paint a clearer picture of cosmic dust formation and has the potential to provide the identification of the carriers of the diffuse interstellar bands and of the 2175 Angstrom feature. The optical properties of dust clusters will be an invaluable ingredient for radiation transfer models in galaxies, star formation, and even for atmospheric studies, since soot and carbonaceous cosmic dust share many similarities.

The results of the research will be disseminated to the public through a collaboration between the PI and the North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences. Dr. Lazzati and museum staff will develop interactive English and Spanish programs for K-12 students and the general public on the evolution of elements and dust in the universe. The programs will eventually be converted into videos that can be shown in museums and schools around the country. Accompanying instructional materials for educators and teachers will be developed. The bilingual character of the activities will be exploited to foster a broader participation of the Hispanic/Latino community in STEM careers. High-school and undergraduate students from underprivileged backgrounds will also join the PI's group for summer research projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT

The main outcome of the project is the characterization of molecular clusters for carbonaceous and silicates grain precursors. These are the nanometer-sized seeds that eventually grow into the stable refractive grains that we see in the cosmos. The properties of the seeds used to be obtained by extrapolation from the properties of macroscopic samples of the materials. In this research, we made for the first time systematic use of ab initio quantum chemcal techniques, such as Density Functional Theory (DFT) to compute the seed physical and thermo-chemical properties from first principles. Among the discoveries performed, two are most significant.

First, it was discovered that the critical size for the seed is constant for a wide range of densities and temperatures, contrary to what previously assumed. The critical size is the size of the smallest stable grain. Grains smaller than the critical size are unstable and tend to evaporate, while grains that are bigger than the critical size grow to become larger stardust particles. A constant critical size enhances dust formation at low temperatures and saturations and has profound implications for the size distribution and composition from cosmic dust producers, such as novae, supernovae, and asymptotic giant branch stars.

Second, it was found that carbonaceous dust formation is more efficient at high density and temperatures than silicate dust formation. This leads to the prediction that dust formation in explosive phenomena, such as novae and supernovae, should begin with carbonaceous grains, while the silicate grains should appear only a few years later. This is a potentially observable prediction and is one of the few known ways in which the microphysics of cosmic dust formation can be tested observationally. 

BROADER IMPACTS

These results have been incorporated in an hands-on activity developed by PI Lazzati for the Oregon Museum of Science and Industry (OMSI). The activity leads the participant through an accelerated voyage from the Big Bang to the formation of planets in the unvierse. A table with a latex membrane is used as a mock universe, covered with white beads that act as hydrogen atoms. Participants can create stars by pulling on the latex membrane and the stars produce metals and grains by inserting colored beads. Then supernivae happen, when the lates is released. The colored beads are dispersed in the model universe and new stars can be formed, this time with metals already in them and the potential for creating planetary systems. This activity has been presented three times per year over a period of two years at OMSI during their "meet ascientist" events, and the plan is to continue presenting it with the same frequency.
